questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with severe allergic reaction symptoms, including urticaria and hypotension, after ingesting a shrimp. How does the vasoactive mediator involved primarily cause hypotension?

choices.text: Dilating arterioles and increasing vascular permeability
Enhancing nitric oxide production and vasodilation
Inducing the release of other pro-inflammatory cytokines
Inhibiting platelet aggregation and causing clotting

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Dilating arterioles and increasing vascular permeability

Explanation:

The scenario indicates an allergic reaction, where histamine acts as the key vasoactive mediator responsible for hypotension by dilating arterioles and increasing vascular permeability, as seen in severe allergic responses like anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Which type of nitric oxide synthase (NOS) is involved in microbial killing and is induced in macrophages by cytokines or microbial products?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Inducible NOS (iNOS)

Explanation:

Inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) is involved in microbial killing.

  • iNOS generates nitric oxide (NO) from Arginine which reacts with superoxide (O2•) to produce peroxynitrite (ONOO−).
    • iNOS works on L-Arginine converting it into Nitric oxide and L-citrulline.
  • Peroxynitrite helps combat infections.

 

Type

Constitutive Expression

Function

 Location

Endothelial (eNOS) (Option A ruled out)

Low levels

Maintains vascular tone

 Blood vessels

Neuronal (nNOS) (Option B ruled out)

Low levels

Functions as a neurotransmitter

 Nerves

Inducible (iNOS) (Option C)

Induced in macrophages(not constitutive expression)

Involved in microbial killing, induced by cytokines or microbial products

  

 

.

questions.text: All are chemoattractants among the following except :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) C3b

Explanation:

Among the given options, C3b is not a chemoattractant.

  • LTB4, IL-8, and C5a  are endogenous chemoattractants. These are primarily involved in neutrophil chemotaxis.
    • Can be learned by a mnemonic: LIC

 

C3b (OPTION D): C3b, C4b, and C5b are opsonins that promote phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages. It is not a chemoattractant.

  • Overall best opsonin in Immunoglobulin G (IgG)
  • The best complement opsonin is C3b.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with symptoms of flu-like illness, including fever, sore throat, and fatigue. Further investigation reveals a positive HIV serology. Which of the following chemokine receptors primarily facilitates the entry of HIV into CD4+ T cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer : B) CCR5 , CXCR4

Explanation:

Among the given options, CCR5 and CXCR4 are the coreceptors that primarily facilitate HIV entry into CD4+ T cells.

  • Whenever HIV enters the body, it targets CD4 T-cells and macrophages in the body.
  • HIV binds to CD4 T cells and macrophages using glycoproteins: GP120 and GP41.
  • Then, coreceptor binding occurs using chemokine receptors like CCR5 and CXCR4.
    • CXCR4 coreceptors are predominantly present on CD4 T-cells
    • CCR5 coreceptors are predominantly present on macrophages.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation. Which of the following chemokines is primarily responsible for recruiting neutrophils to the airways in COPD exacerbations?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) IL-8

Explanation:

Interleukin-8 (IL-8) is a potent chemokine involved in the recruitment of neutrophils to sites of inflammation, particularly in response to bacterial and other microbial infections.

  • IL-8 belongs to the CXC chemokine family.

MCP-1(Option B): Belongs to the CC chemokine family. Primarily recruits monocytes and macrophages to sites of inflammation.

RANTES(Option D): Belongs to the CC chemokine family. Primarily recruits T-cells to sites of inflammation.

SDF-1(Option C): It is a stromal-derived factor. It primarily recruits lymphocytes, monocytes, and hematopoietic stem cells to sites of inflammation.

questions.text: Which of the following mediators is responsible for cancer cachexia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) TNF-alpha

Explanation:

TNF-alpha is responsible for cancer cachexia.

  • Cancer cachexia means weight loss in cancer patients due to the elevation of TNF-alpha mediators.
  • TNF-alpha also learned as no food appetite, because whenever TNF-alpha is raised in the body (can be due to fever or cancer), appetite of patient decreases and they stop feeling hungry.

 

IFN-gamma (Option B) is responsible for granuloma formation.

IL-8 (Option C) is for neutrophil recruitment.

TGF-beta (Option D) is the most fibrogenic cytokine.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male is prescribed naproxen for a musculoskeletal injury. What is naproxen’s mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cycloxygenase (COX) 1 and COX-2 inhibition

Explanation:

Naproxen is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). The predominant action of NSAIDs is via COX-1 and COX-2 inhibition, resulting in analgesia and anti-inflammatory effects which is required in this case of musculoskeletal injury.

One major adverse effect of NSAIDs is gastric irritation, including ulcers and bleeding. This occurs due to the loss of gastroprotective PGs i.e., PGE2, formed by COX-1. Thus, in patients with previous history of gastric ulcers, selective COX-2 inhibitors may be used - celecoxib, etoricoxib, etc.

questions.text:
Select the correct statements about the complement system.

 

1) The complement system primarily functions by adaptive immunity.

2) Complement proteins are solely produced in the liver.

3) All complement proteins are synthesized in inactive forms and are activated by proteolysis.

4) Complement activation occurs through three pathways.

5) Complements have two equal fragments.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 3,4

Explanation: 

The correct statements regarding the complement system are statements 3 and 4.

Complement System:

  • The complement proteins function in both innate and adaptive immunity for defense against microbial pathogens. (Statement 1 ruled out)
  • Site of synthesis: (Statement 2 ruled out)
    • Liver (major site).
    • Monocytes.
    • Tissue macrophages.
    • Epithelial cells of GIT and genitourinary tract.
  • Activation of complement proteins occurs by three pathways: (Statement 4)
    • Classical pathway.
    • Alternative pathway.
    • Lectin pathway.
  • Activation of complement pathway:
    • All complement proteins are synthesized in inactive forms and are activated by proteolysis. (Statement 3)
      • E.g.: Inactive C3 splitting into active C3a and C3b
    • Complements have two unequal fragments (small and large fragments). (Statement 5 ruled out)
      • The larger fragments are designated as ‘b’ (e.g., C3b), and the smaller fragments are designated as ‘a' (e.g., C3a) (exception: C2a—larger fragment).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with a high fever, chills, and malaise. He reports feeling unwell for the past few days and has noticed redness and swelling around a cut on his forearm. On examination, the healthcare provider observes a localized area of erythema and induration at the site of the wound. Which of the following events is a crucial step in the activation of the complement system in response to the patient's initial condition?

choices.text: Binding of C1q to antigen-antibody complexes
Cleavage of C3 into C3a and C3b
Cleavage of C5 by C5 convertase

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cleavage of C3 into C3a and C3b

Explanation:

A 5-year-old male presents with fever, chills, and a swollen, red wound on his forearm; in response to this localized infection, a key step in complement system activation is the cleavage of C3 into C3a and C3b.

Complement system

  • It is a plasma-derived mediator of inflammation.
  • The complement system can be activated by three pathways:
    • Classical pathway
    • Alternate pathway
    • Lectin pathway
  • The cleavage of C3 into its active fragments, C3a and C3b, is the critical event in the complement system and serves as a central step in all three complement activation pathways.

The image below shows an overview of the complement pathways.

questions.text:
Match the following with their correct answers.


	
		
			
			1
			
			
			C3a
			
			
			i
			
			
			Decay accelerating factor
			
		
		
			
			2
			
			
			C3b
			
			
			ii
			
			
			EBV receptor
			
		
		
			
			3
			
			
			CR2
			
			
			iii
			
			
			Anaphylatoxin
			
		
		
			
			4
			
			
			CD55
			
			
			iv
			
			
			Opsonin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-iii, 2-iv, 3-ii, 4-i

Explanation:

  • Anaphylatoxins: C3a, C4a, and C5a.
  • Opsonins: C3b, C4b, and C5b.
    • Opsonins when coats the bacteria, makes it more tasty for phagocytosis.
    • Overall most important opsonin: IgG
    • Most important complement opsonin: C3b
  • CR2/CD21/C3d: Complement receptor 2 for EBV
    • When EBV enters the body, it attacks the B-cells.
    • To enter into B-cells, it uses CD21/CR2.
  • CD55: Decay-accelerating factor (DAF).
  • CD59: Membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis (MIRL)
    • Missing CD55 and CD59 leads to Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the alternate complement pathway?

choices.text: Teichoic acid is an initiator of the alternate complement pathway.
The first complement protein to be activated is C1.
The C3 convertase of the alternate pathway is C3bBb.
Properdin deficiency involves the alternate pathway.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The first complement protein to be activated is C1.

Explanation:

The first complement protein to be activated is C1 in the classical complement pathway and not in the alternative complement pathway.

The complements involved in the alternate pathway are:

  • Free C3 in the serum (alternate complement pathway starts from C3).
  • Factor B.
  • Factor D.
  • Properdin.

Activators (Initiators) of the alternate pathway:

Pathogens from microbes

Non-microbial initiators
  • Gram (-ve) bacteria: Endotoxins or lipopolysaccharides.
  • Gram (+ve) bacteria: Teichoic acid 
  • Fungal cells: Yeast cells.
  • Parasites: Trypanosoma.
  • Virus-infected cells.
  • Human antibodies in complexes: IgA, IgD.
  • Tumor cells.
  • Cobra venom factor.
  • Heterologous RBCs from mice, rabbits, and chickens.
  • Anion polymer like dextran sulfate.
  • Pure carbohydrates like agar and inulin.

 

The image below shows the three complement pathways.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset swelling of her face, lips, and tongue. She reports a history of similar episodes occurring intermittently since childhood, often triggered by stress or trauma. On examination, she appears anxious and has marked swelling of her lips and tongue, with difficulty speaking and swallowing. There are no signs of urticaria or pruritus. Her vital signs are stable. Which of the following deficiencies is seen in this condition?

choices.text: Deficiency of C1, C2, C3, C4

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitor

Explanation:

A 25-year-old female presents with sudden facial, lip, and tongue swelling without urticaria or pruritus, and a history of similar episodes since childhood; this condition is associated with a deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitor.

  • The entire complement pathway, especially the classical pathway, is controlled by C1 inhibitor, which prevents the initiation of the complement pathway. 
  • If C1 esterase inhibitor is missing from the body, it will lead to Hereditary angioneurotic edema, which is a rare autosomal dominant disorder characterised by recurrent episodes of non-pitting, non-pruritic swelling of the skin and mucous membranes.
    • Deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitor leads to elevated plasma levels of bradykinin, leading to angioedema, and excessive activation of C1 results in a decline in plasma C4 and C2 levels.
    • Swelling in HAE commonly affects areas such as the face, lips, tongue, throat, and extremities, and can lead to airway compromise if it involves the upper respiratory tract (laryngeal edema).

questions.text: Which of the following deficiencies is seen in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) CD59

Explanation:

This case is suggestive of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), which is due to the deficiency of CD55 and CD59.

  • PNH is a rare acquired hematologic disorder characterized by a mutation of the PIG-A gene.
  • This mutation results in a deficiency of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)- anchored proteins on the surface of blood cells.
  • This deficiency leads to the absence of important complement regulatory proteins, such as CD55 aka DAF (decay-accelerating factor) and CD59 aka RIML (reactive inhibitor of membrane lysis), which normally protect red blood cells from complement-mediated destruction.
    • Red coloured uring is passed during night
  • Flow cytometry (the gold standard for diagnosis): Shows the absence of CD55 and CD59.

C5-C9 (Option A) is a composition of Membrane Attack Complex (MAC), and its deficiency makes the patient prone to Neisseria meningitidis infections.

C1 (Option C) is associated with autoimmune disorders like SLE.

Factor H (Option D) deficiency causes atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome (Atypical HUS).

questions.text: Pain during inflammation is mediated by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Bradykinin

Explanation:

Bradykinin mediates pain during an inflammatory response

  • Two main mediators of pain are Prostaglandin E2 and Bradykinin.

 

(Serotonin) 

(Option A ruled out)
  • It is responsible for vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, and smooth muscle contraction.
  • In the pathogenesis of asthma, it is responsible for bronchoconstriction.
  • It works similarly to histamine.

(Leukotrienes)

(Option B ruled out)
  • Leukotrienes are lipid mediators synthesized from arachidonic acid metabolism, primarily by the 5-lipoxygenase pathway.
  • Leukotriene B4 is a chemoattractant.
  • Leukotriene C4, D4 and E4 are slow-reacting substances of anaphylaxis playing role in asthma.

(Interleukin-1)

(Option C ruled out)
  • Interleukin-1 (IL-1) is responsible for fever.
